Section D

​

Clearance Level: Public

A dovetail joint is a series of interlocking trapezoidal pins cut into two pieces of wood so they cannot be pulled apart in any direction except the one they were assembled from. No nails. No screws. No glue, if the craftsperson was good enough. Just geometry and pressure.

████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████. The joint doesn't care about your monetary policy. The joint holds.

When we restore a piece with original dovetails, we don't recut them. We clean the surfaces, repair any splits along the grain, and reassemble. The fit is already there. It was always there. A cabinetmaker in ███████████████████████ measured twice and cut once, and that decision is still load-bearing 177 years later.

Modern furniture uses ████████████████████, which is to say: it uses faith. Faith that the dowel won't shear, that the pressboard won't swell, that you won't ever need to move it more than once. A dovetail joint is the opposite of faith. It's proof. It's a woodworker saying: I don't trust the future either, so I made this impossible to break.

That's the whole pitch. We don't trust the future. We make joints that don't require trust.

Section F

​

Q: What happens to my furniture if civilization collapses before the restoration is complete? +

Per Contingency Protocol PAR-CONTINGENCY-7, all in-progress restorations are transferred to our climate-controlled underground storage facility (a root cellar with a padlock and a dehumidifier) within 48 hours of a declared Level 3 or above civilizational disruption event. Refunds will be issued on a barter schedule: 1 completed chair = 6 months of firewood credit or 40 lbs of dried goods, at the discretion of the Reviewing Officer. Your furniture will not be abandoned. We don't abandon things here. That's literally the whole point.

Q: Can you restore IKEA furniture? +

We can. We won't. IKEA furniture is designed to be replaced, which is another way of saying it was designed to be forgotten. We work with pieces that someone intended to last. If your BILLY bookshelf means something to you — if something happened near it that changed your life — call us. We'll make an exception. But you'll have to tell us the story, and it has to be true.

Q: Do you do free estimates? +

Yes. Bring the piece to our shop in Bozeman or send photographs (minimum 6 angles, include any joints, any damage, any areas where the wood has darkened from years of hands touching it). Estimates are returned within 72 hours as a formal assessment document, because if something is worth fixing, it's worth documenting. We also accept pieces sent via freight. Label the box "FRAGILE — EMOTIONAL CARGO." The driver will understand or they won't.

Q: Why is your website formatted like a government form? +

Because the feeling of filling out a form — the low-grade dread, the sense that you are being processed by something larger than yourself, the vague suspicion that no one will actually read this — is the same feeling you get when you think about the future. We wanted you to sit with that. And then we wanted you to notice that you're still here, reading, and your grandmother's chair might still be fixable. Bureaucracy is just hope in an ugly font.
